physDesc.p: Letter consists of 3 pages of typerwriter text. Includes the words "Monroe" and "Poerty" in handwiring at top of the front page above the opener. Text at the top at of page three is crooked showing a typewriter aligmnment malfunction. Misalignment is corrected by the line beginning with "permit the news stands"

body.p: I send you the teaspoonful of "Nationalism in Art" which you vouchsafed me. Your printer is fast becoming the incarnation of the devil, to my mind, and only the fact that you once told me that he was a friend of yours prevents me from lifting my voice and making the welkin ring with my curses. I have corrected this proof which I now return.

May I suggest that “polyethnic” is the correct spelling, not “polyethuic?” A note at the bottom of this proof says that you have already looked it over. Will it be very mean to say that your not having observed that up-side-down letter is one of the reasons why I have a predilection for doing my own proofs? That is why I wired you to send me the remaining tablespoonful.

You do not mind my poking fun at you, do you? I know how beastly proof reading is, and you ought to know by this time how greatly I admire the work you are doing on this magazine, and I send you another at
you might like me to give you <unknown text.

Thanks for your remarks about "The Little Review." I am supporting it for all I am worth by contributions of poems and prose, and I agree with you that it is better than the dull professionalism, but I wish she had your power of making her magazine a first class one.

I hope you have got the advertisement from Macmillans for my book. I put that in on purpose. I wish there were anything I could do to help you, for whatever happens "poetry” must not stop. If I were on the editorial staff I should have a poster printed every month and put in the book shop windows and on all the news stands. I should also try to organize an artificial demand in all the cities, at the book shops, every month, for the magazine. Sometime on the plan by which you “paper” a theatre. If you like, I will undertake to get various people to ask at the Old Corner Book Store for six copies every month of your magazine. I will try to get it done by different people so as to have it appear that each person is anxious for a number. This shall not be subscriptions, but purchases.

Ellery Sӗdgwick tells me that he does not per
mit the news stands booksellers to return any unsold copies of the "Atlantic Monthly" to him. By that basis he knows every month just what he has really sold. I am not sure that it would work with so special a magazine as “Poetry.” I doubt whether the demand, yet, would be big enough to justify the booksellers or news men in purchasing any numbers out right, but you will know your sales about that better than I do.

I really feel awfully about "The Allies," I wish you could have seen your way to publishing it on my responsibility, even against your own judgment I know it would rouse people into liking it and disliking it, which is, after all, what you want in a magazine, and its originality is undoubted. But if you still think you do not want it, at least I trust you will take this "Ballad of Footmen.”
My book will be out next week I think. Don’t you want to review it fairly quickly, as that will help me considerably? You do not answer about Frost’s book.
Mrs. Russell said she had a delightful time with you.
